claim: During the Middle Ages, scholars thought the Earth was round.

supporting.text: Ancient Greek scholars such as Pythagoras and Aristotle argued for a spherical Earth, and their works were preserved and studied by medieval scholars.

attacks.text: Ancient Greek scholars such as Pythagoras and Aristotle argued for a spherical Earth, and their works were preserved and studied by medieval scholars.
While ancient Greek works were preserved, many medieval scholars rejected or ignored these ideas in favor of flat Earth beliefs.
Historical records show that prominent medieval scholars like Thomas Aquinas and Isidore of Seville explicitly supported the spherical Earth theory.
The Catholic Church, which dominated medieval scholarship, suppressed non-religious scientific ideas including the spherical Earth.
The Church actually preserved many Greek scientific texts in monasteries and never officially condemned the spherical Earth theory.

supporting.text: The medieval scholar Thomas Aquinas referenced Aristotle's spherical Earth theory in his works, indicating widespread acceptance among educated individuals.

attacks.text: The medieval scholar Thomas Aquinas referenced Aristotle's spherical Earth theory in his works, indicating widespread acceptance among educated individuals.
Thomas Aquinas was an outlier; most medieval scholars relied on biblical interpretations suggesting a flat Earth.
Historical records show that many medieval universities taught Aristotle's spherical Earth theory as standard curriculum.
Aristotle's spherical Earth theory was often rejected by the Church, which held significant influence over medieval scholarship.
The Church's opposition to Aristotle was primarily theological, not scientific, and many clergy members accepted a spherical Earth.

supporting.text: Medieval maps, such as the T-O maps, were symbolic representations and not literal depictions of a flat Earth, reflecting an understanding of Earth's sphericity.

attacks.text: Medieval maps, such as the T-O maps, were symbolic representations and not literal depictions of a flat Earth, reflecting an understanding of Earth's sphericity.
Some medieval texts explicitly describe the Earth as flat, contradicting the idea that all scholars believed in a spherical Earth.
The flat Earth descriptions in medieval texts were often allegorical or theological, not scientific, and do not represent mainstream scholarly opinion.
T-O maps were often interpreted literally by the general populace, suggesting widespread belief in a flat Earth despite scholarly views.
Historical evidence shows that educated elites, including clergy and scholars, consistently taught the Earth's sphericity, distancing themselves from popular misconceptions.

supporting.text: The concept of antipodes (people living on the opposite side of the Earth) was discussed by medieval scholars, which would only make sense if the Earth were round.

attacks.text: The concept of antipodes (people living on the opposite side of the Earth) was discussed by medieval scholars, which would only make sense if the Earth were round.
Some medieval scholars, like Lactantius, explicitly rejected the idea of a round Earth and antipodes as absurd.
Lactantius was an outlier; most educated medieval scholars accepted the Earth's sphericity based on classical Greek knowledge.
The discussion of antipodes was often theoretical or allegorical, not necessarily proof of widespread belief in a round Earth.
Medieval astronomical and geographical works, like those of Bede and Sacrobosco, explicitly described the Earth as spherical.

supporting.text: Astronomical observations, such as the curvature of Earth's shadow during lunar eclipses, were cited by medieval scholars as evidence for a spherical Earth.

attacks.text: Astronomical observations, such as the curvature of Earth's shadow during lunar eclipses, were cited by medieval scholars as evidence for a spherical Earth.
Some medieval scholars, like Lactantius and Cosmas Indicopleustes, explicitly argued for a flat Earth based on religious texts.
Lactantius and Cosmas were fringe figures; mainstream medieval scholarship overwhelmingly supported a spherical Earth.
The curvature of Earth's shadow could also be explained by a disk-shaped Earth, not necessarily a sphere.
A disk-shaped Earth would not produce a consistently circular shadow during lunar eclipses from different vantage points.

supporting.text: The Venerable Bede, an early medieval scholar, explicitly described the Earth as round in his writings, demonstrating knowledge of its shape.

attacks.text: The Venerable Bede, an early medieval scholar, explicitly described the Earth as round in his writings, demonstrating knowledge of its shape.
Bede's writings were not widely read or influential outside monastic circles, limiting their impact on broader medieval scholarship.
Despite limited circulation, Bede's works were copied and preserved in monastic libraries, ensuring some scholarly continuity.
Some early medieval maps like the T-O maps depicted a flat Earth, contradicting Bede's round Earth description.
T-O maps were schematic representations for religious purposes, not literal geographical depictions.
